PM11:07am

We would like to be able to predict black swans, but by definition they are unpredictable.
However, its close cousin the grey swan can be foreseen. These are the unlikely but
impactful events that, in our opinion, lie outside the usual base case and risk scenarios
of the analyst community. So as we did last year we have put on our creative hats and
have come up with 10 potential grey swan events for 2018.

Boycott Have Exane not done their 12 days of Christmas notes this year? Previous years have seen some output that was worth sharing.
alewis2005 i.e. friends company ski trip, complete with many beginners, went to Bulgaria instead of the traditional french/austrian alps
PM11:07am

Ok, here are the 10...

PM11:07am

Shock 1: What the movies tell us about 2018
Shock 2: The “Amazonification” of inflation
Shock 3: 2% inflation targeting goes out of style
Shock 4: A United States of Europe
Shock 5: Another UK political turnaround
Shock 6: Bitcoin starts moving other markets
Shock 7: Housing market decline = rate cuts?
Shock 8: A bigger proxy war in the Middle East
Shock 9: “Get to the chopper!”
Shock 10: Credit: stealth leverage pops?

1: What the movies tell us about 2018

PM11:09am

Films may end up being better predictors of grey swans than research analysts.
Remember it was a film that first predicted a black president of the US (The Man, 1972),
the rise of China as an economic powerhouse (Americathon, 1979) and the rise of
tabloid TV (Network, 1976). As it happens, we’ve found three notable movies that are
based in 2018, and here’s what they foretell.

The 2009 film, Terminator Salvation, is set specifically in 2018. The backdrop is a conflict
between Skynet and the human resistance. For the uninitiated Skynet is a computer
system developed for the US military by Cyberdyne Systems. The system was intended
to safeguard the world by pre-empting attacks. However, it soon developed artificial
general intelligence and decided that humans were the biggest threat to the planet.
Skynet among other things could control mobile phones, drones and cyborgs/
Terminators (or as Arnie says in Terminator 2: “I'm a cybernetic organism. Living tissue
over a metal endoskeleton”).

PM11:10am

It would be easy to dismiss this 2018 scenario, but let’s run through the necessary
ingredients for it to emerge. We would need the existence of drones, computer-controlled
power grids and networked transportation and food systems. Layered on top of this, we
would need AI/machine learning capabilities. What would make the system much more
fragile would be the replacement of all physical forms of mediums of exchange such as
gold by say a cryptocurrency …hmmm, is Skynet reading this?

PM11:11am

If this isn’t scary enough then 2018 could prove to be like it was depicted in the 1975 film
Rollerball. This is when the world is run by a global energy monopoly, Energy
Corporation. Energy Corp wishes to replace warfare with a violent sport called Rollerball,
which consists of two teams racing around a circular track on roller skates attacking each
other. The plot of the movie hinges around the star player of Rollerball becoming too
popular for Energy Corp and they try to get him killed in a match. He, of course, survives
and reveals the nature of Energy Corp to the world.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

The essence of the movie is that behind any veneer of democracy and competition, there
lays a corporate imperative to distract the masses with mindless and often violent
entertainment. To be honest, many would subscribe to this view already! But to reach the
scales of Rollerball control, we would need one or two global companies emerging to
dominate the world – ideally in sectors that can distract us with fake news, fun games
and constant distractions. Surely we’re not close to that are we?

Mouselet (the obvious triggering event would be Falcon Heavy doing an N1 imitation)

PM11:12am

Finally...

PM11:12am

Finally, I can’t ignore the 2012 film Iron Sky. Don’t laugh, but the plot revolves around a
manned mission to the dark side of moon in 2018, where the descendants of Nazis are
discovered. These Moon Nazis take some technology from the astronauts and invade
Earth. Film connoisseurs will know that this is an unlikely scenario as the 2011 film
Transformers Dark Side of the Movie already told us that the Decepticon transformers
are on the dark side of the moon. They would have easily wiped out the Moon Nazis. But
hang on, it would also mean that there would now be a fleet of Decepticons ready to
invade the Earth in 2018….

Here's Investec

PM11:37am

Late on Friday, ESMA made an announcement stating that it is considering the possible use of its product intervention powers
under Article 40 of MIFIR to restrict the marketing, distribution or sale to retail clients of CFDs, including spot forex, and
prohibiting the marketing, distribution or sale of binary options to retail clients. The restrictions under review in relation to
CFDs are 1). Decreasing leverage limits on the opening of a position between 30:1 and 5:1, with lower leverage limits applied
to more volatile products, 2). Margin close-out rules, 3). Negative balance protection to ensure clients cannot lose more than
the balance in their trading accounts, 4). A restriction on benefits incentivising trading, and 5). The implementation of
standardised risk warnings. ESMA is planning to conduct a consultation in January 2018 on the above. Any intervention
measure adopted can have an initial duration of up to 3 months and is renewable. The FCA has also commented saying that
its measures, which are currently under review, will take in to account any prospective ESMA measures. We expect the FCA
to announce the finalisation of its permanent measures in Q118, and for those measures to be similar to ESMA’s in an effort
to harmonise regulation across the FCA and ESMA.

Flaneur (@IK - I have often thought that about Tor...)
11:37 am
PM11:37am

Binary options (which ESMA may ban for retail clients), represents less than 5% of revenue. IG believes that the leverage
restrictions under review are disproportionate and go beyond what is needed to protect consumers. IG also believes that the
announced regulatory measures may push retail clients to trade CFDs with unregulated firms based outside the EU. Since
mid-November, the proportion of revenue in the UK and EU from professional clients (considered non-retail) has increased
from 5% to 15%. IG believes that clients representing well over 50% of current UK and EU revenue are eligible to be
categorised as professional and will elect to be treated as such if the products that they can trade and the leverage they can
utilise diverges from that available to retail clients. The impact to historic revenue after actions taken by IG would be less
than 10% (including Binaries), and we believe that this, combined with cost mitigation in relation to marketing costs and
resource allocation, would mean the future impact is immaterial. We note that, on the 30 November 2016 (before the FCA
proposal announcement), IG’s share price was £8.41, 14.7% higher than today’s share price

urgeview h1 , unlikely to ever happen, over 70% of transactions on LSE are cfd's
PM11:38am

On Friday ESMA indicated that their review into the retail CFD market is ongoing and a public consultation will be conducted in January 18, with official restrictions to be announced thereafter. In particular it highlights that matters under review include 1) leverage limits on the opening of a position between 30:1 and 5:1 are under consultation, 2) negative balance protection 3) prohibition of sale of binary options to retail clients 3) restriction of marketing, distribution or sale to retail clients of CFDs, including rolling spot forex. This will be a concern, particularly when some instruments from some providers offer 250:1 to 500:1 leverage. In a statement this morning, Plus500 has clarified that it has never offered binary options and has always provided balance protection to its customers across all its product offerings in all its markets. Plus500 also has a maintenance margin level which enables its customers to have additional protection and in January 2017, is removed its bonus schemes for the vast majority of its operations. Plus500 indicates that until the details are finalised, “it is difficult to assess the impact upon our business,” but note that operating lisences in 7 jurisdictions globally should provide some protection to the business. Nonetheless, some adjustments are likely to be necessary in our view. We expect the CFD providers (CMC Group, IG Group, Plus500) to go weaker on the ESMA update as the leverage restrictions are likely to have an impact.

Earthport’s trading update indicates a weak end to cal’17, with delays to new client implementations and the loss of a major piece of business resulting in 17% revenue downgrades to FY’18. Despite these setbacks, the medium term outlook remains positive. The new business pipeline is extremely healthy and an existing client expansion worth over 1 million incremental transactions annually is ramping up after starting earlier this month. The group has also announced that Hank Uberoi will move to Executive Chairman to focus on strategic opportunities. While the setback in FY’18 is highly disappointing, we continue to believe that Earthport is well placed to corner a significant slice of the vast cross border payments market and that the changes announced today will maximise the group’s ability to fulfil its potential.

PM11:59am

The housebuilders outperformed by c.30% in 2017, mainly due to strong first-time buyers and government help. We do not see clear or present dangers for the cycle and expect continued resilience. But slower selling price rises and stubborn build cost inflation may curtail margin progress, limiting scope for outperformance to the growers: cheaper and with improving returns. Our only BUYs are Bellway, Galliford Try, Gleeson* and Redrow.

PM11:59am

We prefer growers to returners: cheaper with better EPS prospects as selling price inflation slows. Bellway and Redrow have long track records of profitable volume growth. Gleeson*'s unique low cost model is delivering strong returns and rapid growth. Galliford Try's historic construction woes weigh dis-proportionately and growing housing and partnerships are ignored. Barratt is Sell rated as dividends look least safe and margins unexciting. We have not made estimate changes, but raised target prices by c6% as we move from Jun18 to Dec18 target

PM11:59am

What’s next?

The housebuilders had a surprisingly strong year in 2017, starting from a low base, out-performing UK stocks by c30%. Success was driven by the strength of first-time buyers (who find buying cheaper than rent), Help to Buy, inventory availability and being underweight London. We expect continued resilience as these forces remain, but house price inflation is likely to slow and build cost inflation persist, making it tougher to keep improving margins in the absence of better volumes or self-improvement.

11:59 am
PM12:00pm

How will it end?

We have looked at seven possible forces that could bring an end to the cycle, and conclude that none of these is a clear and present danger. We look at affordability, the likelihood of recession, mortgage availability, interest rates, macroprudential regulation, changes to net migration and a Corbyn government. The most likely cause for an end to the cycle would be a recession, although the outlook is not all bad; tightening macroprudential rules on mortgages would also prove painful.
